data.title: Vishay Intertechnology Non-GAAP EPS of $0.00 misses by $0.08, revenue of $714.7M misses by $6.81M
data.description:
• Vishay Intertechnology press release (NYSE:VSH): Q4 Non-GAAP EPS of $0.00 misses by $0.08.
  • Revenue of $714.7M (-9.0% Y/Y) misses by $6.81M.
  • 4Q 2024 book-to-bill of 1.01, with book-to-bill of 0.99 for semiconductors and 1.03 for passive components
  • Backlog at quarter end was 4.4 months
  • 1Q 2025 OutlookFor the first quarter of 2025, management expects revenues in the range of $710 million +/- $20 million and a gross profit margin in the range of 19.0% +/- 50 basis points, including the negative impact of approximately of 175-200 basis points related to Newport.

data.title: LiveWire Group narrows its operating loss in Q4 despite a sales slump
data.description:
LiveWire Group (NYSE:LVWR) reported electric balance bike units of 8,350 in Q4, compared to 8,354 a year ago. Consolidate revenue was down 29% to $10.8 million for the quarter that ended on December 31. The electric motorcyles segment saw a revenue decline of 56% to $3.5 million, while the STACYC segment saw a 2% increase to $7.3 million.

LiveWire (NYSE:LVWR) narrowed its consolidated operating loss by $8.5 million from 2023, driven by a decrease in consolidated selling, administrative and engineering expense.

Looking ahead, LiveWire (LVWR) expects to reduce its cash burn by 40% or more in 2025 compared to 2024. The company also plans to continue establishing its leadership in the EV space. "With our world-class products, first-class team, and best-in-the-industry retail partners, we will continue to relentlessly improve the fundamentals of the business and position ourselves for long-term success," stated CEO Karim Donnez. The company expects electric motorcycle sales of 1,000 to 1,500 revenue units for 2025 and an operating loss of $70 million to $80 million.

Shares of LiveWire Group (LVWR) were up 1.0% in premarket trading. The electric motorcycle manufacturer stock is down more than 70% over the last 52 weeks.

data.title: Earnings Snapshot: Uber's Q4 gross bookings, trips jump 18% Y/Y
Old Dominion Freight Line GAAP EPS of $1.23 beats by $0.07, revenue of $1.39B beats by $10M
data.description:
• Old Dominion Freight Line press release (NASDAQ:ODFL): Q4 GAAP EPS of $1.23 beats by $0.07.
  • Revenue of $1.39B (-7.3% Y/Y) beats by $10M.
  • Quarterly Cash Dividend to Increase 7.7% to $0.28 Per Share.

  • Old Dominion’s net cash provided by operating activities was $401.1 million for the fourth quarter of 2024 and $1.7 billion for the year.

  • The company had $108.7 million in cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2024.

  • Capital expenditures were $170.9 million for the fourth quarter of 2024 and $771.3 million for the year.

  • The company expects its aggregate capital expenditures for 2025 to total approximately $575 million, including planned expenditures of $300 million for real estate and service center expansion projects; $225 million for tractors and trailers; and $50 million for information technology and other assets.

data.title: Fiserv Non-GAAP EPS of $2.51 beats by $0.03, revenue of $5.25B beats by $290M

• Fiserv press release (NYSE:FI): Q4 Non-GAAP EPS of $2.51 beats by $0.03.

data.title: Spire Non-GAAP EPS of $1.34, revenue of $669.1M
data.description:
• Spire press release (NYSE:SR): Q1 Non-GAAP EPS of $1.34.
  • Revenue of $669.1M (-11.6% Y/Y).
  • Spire continues to expect fiscal 2025 adjusted earnings to be in the range of $4.40–$4.60 per share. We remain confident in our ability to grow long-term adjusted earnings per share 5–7% driven by an expected long-term 7–8% annualized rate base growth at Spire Missouri, reflecting our robust capital investment plan, and 6% equity growth at Spire Alabama and Spire Gulf.

data.title: European markets mostly lower amid escalating trade tensions, and earnings flurry, yields dip
data.description:
Update: The revised post reflects market movements as of 6.45am ET.

London (UKX) +0.11% UK's service activity drops in January

Germany (DAX:IND) -0.04% Germany's service activity growth hits six-month high.

France (CAC:IND) -0.15% France service activity falls in January. Industrial production fell 0.4% M/M in December.

Iceland’s Central Bank cut its key interest rate by 50 bps to 8.0%, aligning with market expectations.

The annual inflation rate in Luxembourg rose to 1.94% in January.

The Services PMI in Sweden fell to 50.1 in January

Spain's service PMI drops in January.

Retail sales in the Czech Republic advanced by 6.2% Y/Y in December.

The pan-European Stoxx 600 (STOXX) climbed 0.18% as investors watched escalated trade tensions between U.S. and China.

The euro (EUR:USD) strengthened above $1.04 as the US dollar weakened, with investors reacting to the potential economic impact of President Trump's trade tariffs.

In corporate news, Novo Nordisk posted stronger-than-expected profits for Q4 driven by a 107% surge in sales of its Wegovy weight loss drug. Among other companies posting earnings include: Banco Santander (SAN), Credit Agricole, GSK (GSK) reported Q4 results and raised long-term outlook, Handelsbanken, and TotalEnergies. TotalEnergies (TTE) beat top-line and bottom-line estimates; initiates FY25 outlook.

In the bond market, the U.S. 10-year Treasury yield down 3 basis points to 4.48%.

Germany's 10-year yield down 4 basis points to 2.36%.

UK's 10-year yield was down 6 basis points to 4.47%.

Currencies: (EUR:USD) (GBP:USD) (CHF:USD)

ETFs: (EWG), (GF), (EWI), (EWQ), (FGM), (DAX), (FLGR), (FXB), (EWU), (FKU), (EWUS), (FLGB), (GREK).

data.title: Mortgage applications slightly higher as interest rates ease
data.description:
• MBA Mortgage Applications
  • Composite Index: +2.2% vs. -2.0% a week ago.
  • 30-year fixed-rate mortgages came in at 6.97%, compared to 7.02% last week.
